Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Bifunctional Catalysts for the Hydrogenation and Dehydrogenation of Polar Bonds
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Anthony Chianese of Colgate University is developing new catalysts to enable the chemical storage of solar energy and the more environmentally benign synthesis of important industrial materials. This project has potential significance in increasing the atom efficiency and sustainability of redox transformations of polar bonds. As the research is conducted entirely by undergraduate students, the project will facilitate the training of future scientists.

The project is directed at the development and mechanistic characterization of ruthenium- and iron-pincer catalysts for the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation of polar bonds. In particular, the project focuses on using the highly abundant metal iron as a replacement for rarer and more expensive ruthenium. The primary goal is to pursue the development of iron catalysts for currently unknown transformations, such as the hydrogenation of esters and amides and the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to give methanol, as well as the corresponding dehydrogenation reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the development of new catalysts for an important organic chemical reaction: the hydrogenation of ester substrates. The project was dedicated to two main goals: 1) To prepare a diverse set of potential catalysts, with the aim of understanding how their molecular structure impacts catalyst activity; and 2) working to understand the intimate molecular details of how the reaction operates. The work resulted in the discovery of a highly active catalyst, and we learned that a catalyst with larger organic groups crowding the active site was more robust and more active. Significant progress has also been made in understanding how our catalyst works, through experimental and computational studies.

This project was conducted entirely by the principal investigator and 15 undergraduate students at Colgate University. In addition to the scientific advanced made, these students received important training in the conduct of science and the dissemination of scientific information. Students contributed substantially to the writing of manuscripts for publication, and presented their work at American Chemical Society National Meetings. These students received training in the ethical conduct of scientific research. They also participated with the principal investigator in an outreach activity each summer, designed to introduce high school students from disadvantaged backgrounds to the excitment of scientific research in synthetic chemistry.
